entry.title: A Post Quantum Migration Proposal
entry.summary:
The recent discussions on the Bitcoin Development Mailing List have brought to light innovative strategies for integrating quantum resistance into Bitcoin's existing framework. A key focus is on the use of ECDSA's R-values and public keys in transaction signatures, highlighting a method by which Bitcoin could evolve to accommodate quantum-resistant mechanisms without immediate overhaul of its current systems.
In Bitcoin's transaction verification process, the public key and an R-value—a component of the signature—are crucial elements. While the public key associated with a transaction cannot be altered once it has been included in the output Script, the R-value presents an opportunity for adaptation because it can be freely chosen by the signer at the time of transaction creation. This flexibility allows for the possibility of embedding quantum-resistant data within the R-value by hashing quantum data and forming a valid commitment within it. Such a technique suggests that while traditional nodes would continue to operate using standard ECDSA signatures and public keys, new or upgraded nodes equipped to handle quantum information could interpret additional commitments made within the R-value.
The proposal outlines a phased approach to introducing quantum resistance. Initially, quantum commitments within the R-value would be optional, enabling a gradual transition where transactions remain valid under the traditional ECDSA scheme while incorporating quantum-resistant features for forward-looking nodes. Over time, as quantum resistance becomes a necessity, the protocol could mandate that all R-values in transaction signatures commit to a valid quantum signature, seamlessly integrating quantum resistance into the verification process.
Moreover, this approach addresses potential concerns regarding blockchain scalability and the introduction of quantum data. The incorporation of quantum commitments is not expected to be constrained by Bitcoin's current block size limits but would instead be regulated by a combination of the existing sigops limit and a new, adjustable quantum commitment size limit. This limit could vary based on the specific requirements of different quantum-resistant signature schemes, offering a flexible framework to support varying degrees of quantum data.
This dialogue among developers underscores an ongoing commitment to ensuring Bitcoin's resilience in the face of advancing quantum computing capabilities, demonstrating a proactive and strategic approach to future-proofing the network while maintaining operational continuity during the transition period.
